en.value: His bag is not u[k]n[/k]d[k]e[/k][k]r[/k] the bed.
However, some prepositions of place do not have opposites.
There are some good bars and restaurants.
My house is on a short street.
This sentence contains a preposition of place.
Wow! Your flat is quite big, Michael.
We work in a really modern office.
John lives in a small flat in London.
Many prepositions of place come in pairs of opposites.
Select the adverb you hear in the audio.
Did you notice that the adverb "quite" and the adjective "quiet" are spelt similarly? Be careful and try to remember how to spell both words correctly!
Anna is talking to an estate agent about viewing a flat.
The food is on the table.
The party is at my friend's house.
The green house is [k]between[/k] a pink house and a blue house.
Adverbs like quite, very, really, so go before the adjective.
My flat is [k]above[/k] a small shop.
The flat [k]below[/k] mine is very noisy.
A: How many rooms do you have?
My parents watch TV in the living room.
Prepositions are used to give information about the noun that they are used with. Prepositions of place specifically give information about the location of nouns.
Oh good. That part of town is [k]so[/k] beautiful, too.
With types of transport, we use "on". Except with cars, when we use "in".
Have you noticed that adverbs normally go before the adjectives? Look at the structure and examples below.
We don't have a living room.
Describing our house or flat - Adjectives and quantifiers: very, quite, really, etc.
We're staying in a small flat in the city centre.
OK. We have a very [k]modern[/k] flat, not far from the station.
It has two [k]bedrooms[/k] and a nice living room.
My car is [k]in front of[/k] my house.
It is so quiet in here.
My car is [k]i[/k]n f[k]r[/k][k]o[/k]nt o[k]f[/k] my house.
We use the word "room" to refer to any room in a building, house or flat.
Select the words in the correct order.
Select all the rooms in the house.
There is one bedroom in my flat.
My car is in front of my house.
"Really" and "very" are similar in meaning. Have a look at the example below.
How many rooms are there in the house?
How many bedrooms are there in the flat?
The bathroom is between my bedroom and the lounge.
My apartment is below two smaller apartments.
They live in an old house.
Which room do we cook in?
The lounge is next to the kitchen.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
In the sentence the adjective goes before the adverb.
His bag is not [k]under[/k] the bed.
Describe these spaces using as many adverbs and adjectives as you can.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
The brown car is [k]next to[/k] the blue car.
B: We have four rooms: a living room, a bedroom, a bathroom and a kitchen.
We’re now going to learn how to describe our house or flat. First, we’ll look at words for describing the place in general; then we’ll learn some names of different rooms.
The flat below mine is very noisy.
His bag is not under the bed.
Mike has a big apartment in New York.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
It sounds good! When can I see it?
The garden is b[k]e[/k][k]h[/k][k]i[/k]nd the house.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Your living room is really modern.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
We're staying in a small flat in the city centre.
Here pretty has a similar meaning to quite.
Margaret and Mike are catching up at work.
The green house is [k]b[/k]e[k]t[/k][k]w[/k][k]e[/k]e[k]n[/k] a pink house and a blue house.
Her flat is new and trendy.
Select the adjective you hear in the audio.
We use the word "room" to refer to any room.
How many rooms are there in your house?

We've just learned how to talk about the place you live in using words such as "old" and "modern". We call these words "adjectives". They help us to describe people and objects in more detail. Have a look at some other examples below.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Well it's [k]very[/k] modern, but the living room is [k]quite[/k] cosy.

We can use adverbs along with adjectives if we want to give more information about something. Adverbs modify an adjective's meaning and can also give emphasis. Have a look at some of them highlighted below.
Oh great. How big is it?
The bike is outside the garage.
My flat is [h]above[/h] a small shop.
They live in a very big apartment.
Your new kitchen is very modern.
The shorter prepositions (in, on, at) in English tend to be quite tricky. It's not always obvious as to which one we should use, so it's best to learn it case by case.
You can also use the adverb "pretty". It has a a similar meaning to "quite", but is more informal.
I live in a three-bedroom house with a nice living room and a modern kitchen.
The green house is between the pink house and the blue house..
Her house is [k]old[/k], but really nice.
Click on the preposition of place in each sentence.
The lounge is next to the kitchen.
The garden is behind the house.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
flat kitchen bedroom [h]apartment[/h] bathroom living room
While in the UK people say "flat", in the US people are more likely to use the word "apartment".
It is so quiet in here.
The brown car is next to the blue car.
It is a nice living room and a modern [k]kitchen[/k].
We only use the word "room" to talk about a bathroom.
Fill in the gap using the image.
We have a nice apartment in a busy street in London.
It has two [k]bedrooms[/k], a nice [k]living room[/k], a new [k]kitchen[/k] and [k]bathroom[/k].
The brown car is [k]next to[/k] the blue car.
The party is at my house.
Let's learn a couple of other adjectives that will help you to describe your objects even better.
My flat is above a small shop.
Hi. I'm looking for a [k]flat[/k] in the city centre.
I live in a big house not far from London.
They live in a very big flat.
I live in a nice house.
